segments.text: Testing on Friday, testing on Friday, 1, 2, 3.
Testing 2, 3, 4 on Friday, 2, 3, 4.
Testing this, this is Monday the 28th.
Testing, testing, testing, testing, testing.
This is Monday, June 28th.
What's the name of this building?
We were in the Central Square building.
Central Square building on North Central Expressway in Dallas, and I have the honor and pleasure of chatting with John Creighton.
That's C-R-I-C-H-T-O-N. And known to my friends as Jack.
As Jack, but pronounced Creighton.
Right.

To introduce yourself, sir, to anyone who might hear this tape or read the transcription, give us a brief biographical summary of your experience in life from growing up, mom and dad, before you got to A&M.
I was born in a little town in Louisiana named after my grandfather of Creighton, Louisiana.
My grandfather owned a cotton plantation and a steamboat landing.
And in 1916, he sold this plantation to the Palmer Brothers in Chicago, who owned the Palmer House, among other things.
And after he sold this plantation, they struck oil on it.
And over a number of years, I took out several million barrels of oil.
And I've been trying to get even with the oil business ever since then, because my grandfather didn't retain any interest in this.
My father was a graduate of LSU.
My mother was a schoolteacher that went to Louisiana Normal in Natchitoches, Louisiana.
And my father ran the plantation for the Palmer brothers for a number of years.
And then he and an associate bought out the Palmer brothers' interest, and he continued to run the plantation.
raising cotton and cattle, mostly.
And my father died when I was 12 years old.
I attended grade school in a... Creighton did not have school facilities when I grew up, and I attended a school in East Point, Louisiana, three miles away.
And it was a very good academic school.
Also, I played on the basketball team at East Point.
And then my senior year, I stayed with my aunt in Shreveport, Louisiana, and went to school at Byrd High School.
where I played basketball on the Byrd High team and was the leading scorer at Byrd and held a school scoring record for several years.
Then I decided I wanted to take petroleum engineering as a means of getting even with the oil business because my grandfather sold out without retaining any of it.
And I went to see Mr. McGowan, who was the president of the United Gas Company.
Mr. McGowan had been the auditor, had been the accountant for the Palmer Brothers.
He and my father had gotten to be very good friends.
So as I say, my father died when I was 12.
And so I went up to see Mr. McGowan.
I said, I want to take petroleum engineering.
Where should I go to school?
He said, well, our experience has been that graduates of University of Oklahoma and Texas A&M have been the best that we've hired.
And he said, if you're interested in the military, Texas A&M is the place to go.
He said, we have a plane.
And mind you, this is 1933.
He said, we have a plane going down to Houston taking Mr. Hargrove, the vice president, for a meeting.
And en route to Houston, we'll drop you off at College Station.
And of course, there was no airfield at College Station at that time.
So sure enough, we took off.
It was a twin-engine beach.
I remember the pilot's name was Eddie Heffley.
And when we got over College Station, we circled around and Eddie looked for a place to land and finally found an alfalfa field that looked suitable.
So we landed in this alfalfa field.
Farmers came from everywhere to see this plain land.
And so I got off the plane and looked like I was received as somebody who just got down from Mars.
And I caught a ride.
hitchhiked into town, into College Station, and the petroleum engineering building had just been built.
I talked to some people there.
I went around the campus, talked to various people, and liked the military, and the people were so friendly.
and everybody howdy and answered any question I wanted to ask.
So I highwayed back to the alfalfa field.
And sure enough, at 3.30, the plane returned from Houston, circled around again.
Farmers came from miles to see the plane land, and landed, picked me up, went back to Shreveport, and I reported back to Mr. McGowan that I decided to go to A&M.
That was how I first got interested in A&M, and that's how I ended up at A&M.
And that visit was about what time of the year?
That visit must have been in around May or June of that year.
Then your goal was to be a petroleum engineer, and what did you think you were going to do with that degree?
Well, what I thought I was going to do was make some money out of it.
So anyway, I entered Texas A&M not knowing the traditions they had there, only that I had also checked with other people and found out A&M had a very good academic reputation.
and also that it was affordable as to the amount of money you had to spend, and also like the military.
So I had an uncle who was a captain in the
Field Artillery, regular Army.
I visited him several times up at Fort Robinson, Nebraska.
And so that was the horse-drawn field artillery, and I liked to ride.
And so he taught me English-style riding, although I had known how to ride growing up on the plantation.
And so I joined the field artillery, E Battery Field Artillery.
And anyway, like I say, I was not acquainted with the traditions.
And I remember that first, about the first three nights we were there, they had a meeting of all the freshmen
on the YMCA steps.
And they had greeted us, somebody greeted us and welcomed us to the college.
And all at once somebody whipped out a Sam Brown belt and said, air out, Fish.
I didn't know what was happening.
until I got hit on the leg several times and I decided that running was the only thing to do, which I did with the rest of the fish.
And I think I spent the night out in the woods there and came back the next day.
And that was my introduction to the traditions at A&M.
When you came to enroll in September, how did you get from
Northwest Louisiana at the College Station.
Interesting.
I came by train and left from Shreveport.
I forget it was quite a long train trip and at Hearn you had to change trains there.
Hearn was quite a railroad center at that time and so had about a two or three hour layover in Hearn until we
got on the train going to College Station.
And I had a, I think I had a steamer truck, which I had a heck of a time getting from the station to the, from the station to College Station.
to the room I'd been assigned to.
What did you bring with you as a freshman?
What was in that truck?
I knew you had military uniforms, but I had athletic equipment.
and, of course, some business-type clothes and some social-type clothes, a lot of shoes, and I was pretty well outfitted.
And then, of course, I got the uniforms when I got to College Station.
And I remember we were assigned to Hart Hall.
It was a new
building at that time.
And I roomed with a fellow named Phelps Lommadew, who was from Port Arthur.
And he, his last name translated, I think, is Man of God.
L-A-M-B-A-R. Phelps was his first name.
L-Lamadu.
H-O-M-M-E-D-I-E-U.
Oh.
Phelps Lamadu.
And he had been a star quarterback on the Fort Arthur football team.
And there was a great rivalry between Port Arthur and Beaumont at that time.
I guess there always has been.
And we had two guys from, played on the football team at Beaumont, two in Port Arthur, and they had a great rivalry.
Describe your freshman room.
What did you and Phelps have in that room?
In that room, we had two desks.
I had a radio and a double bunk bed, and you flipped to see who had the top bunk and who had the bottom bunk.
And it was a nice room, and I forget
whether we had a washbowl in it.
I'm sure the John was a community John.
And what we roomed, oddly enough, we roomed between two seniors' rooms, and this was on the second floor, and the
It wasn't too long before we found out what we were supposed to do.
The sophomores called a meeting and told us what we were required to do, and I was assigned to be the room orderly for one of the seniors next door.
I happened to be the captain of the battery.
Captain, his name was Charlie Swanson.
I remember he roomed with a guy named Yuki Porter, and the, but the sophomores told us our duties and so forth, and then introduced us to the, to hazing, and
At that time, I remember about 18 sophomores.
The reason I remember the exact number is that each one of them got three licks at you, which adds up to 54.
So I can divide that by three and get the number 18 rather readily.
What did they use for paddles?
The paddles were sawed off and shaved off baseball bats for the most part.
But they were thin.
They were sawed off quite a bit.
It was not like a whole baseball bat.
It stung pretty good, but you soon learned that after the first several licks, why, your buttocks got sort of numb, and it didn't hurt too much.
And anyway, if a sophomore hits you low, why, you had licks on him.
So they were pretty accurate on where they hit you because if they hit you lower, you could say, okay, it's my turn, you know.
Your outfit, what was it?
E Battery Field Artillery.
Did it have a nickname?
No, I don't recall, but that battery was noted for winning intramurals.
We were intramural champions, which was a big deal in the A&M at that time.
And that tradition continued.
As a matter of fact, when
When I became captain of the battery in my senior year, when the freshmen checked in, we went down to the registration line and we recruited guys by sports.
So that we ended up with some guys who weren't quite good enough, let's say, to make the football team or the basketball team, but were pretty good athletes.
And we continued to win the intramural.
How did the outfit introduce you and your fish buddies to A&M traditions?
How did they explain things and tell you what you were to do and not to do?
The sophomores took care of that.
The sophomores called you together on that.
And you had mentioned Colonel Anderson, who was a great guy.
I ran cross-country under Colonel Anderson because he was the track coach, and then he became commandant.
And Colonel Anderson was a man who instilled character in the guys who ran for him.
And as later I recall, there was one incident where a guy crawled across the finish line and actually won the meet for him.
But Colonel Anderson, I remember him for another reason.
When I was captain of the battery,
there was some hazing going on in my battery.
And so he called me over and he said, Jack, I want you to get the names of those sophomores that did this hazing, understand there's been some hazing.
He said, I want to inspect them.
And I said, fine, come over and inspect them, Colonel.
So lined up all the fish, and they dropped their trousers.
And the man, their buttocks were just blue as a grape.
And he said, Jack, I want you to get the names of those sophomores that did this.
And I said, what are you going to do with them, Colonel?
He said, I'm going to kick them out.
And I said, well, in that case, Colonel, I'm sorry, I just can't do that.
And he said, you're busted.
Hand me over your buttons.
So I peeled off my buttons and gave them to him.
He said, you have to march in ranks.
So this I did for the next week.
And at the end of the week,
Colonel Anderson called me over and he said, Jack, I've decided not to kick these guys out of school.
I'm going to put them on the bull ring for the rest of the year.
And I said, in that case, Colonel, I'll get you their names.
So I went back to the fish and I said, give me the names of the sophomores that did this.

and I said the colonel gives me his word he's not going to kick these guys out of school so anyway they turned in a list of the people and it turned out that these fish had turned in the names of just the sophomores they didn't like and two or three of them had been in Houston when this happened and so I turned the names into the colonel and he put all these guys on the bull ring including these
guys who were innocent from Houston.
But anyway, I think that was one of the best experiences of my
being at A&M actually was the, was being, you went from a fish to a corporal, then a sergeant, then to an officer.
And I was first sergeant in my outfit, and then I got to be captain.
and a captain of an outfit had a lot of responsibilities and has to make a lot of decisions.
And this was wonderful training that I wouldn't take anything for.
In those first, how did you register for your academics that first semester?
Do you remember how?
Yeah, we went to the, I'm not exactly sure, but you had certain requirements according to what you had signed up for.
Like I've taken petroleum engineering, and you had to take some basic courses, English and so forth.
As a freshman year, you didn't have too many options, but as time went on, sophomores and juniors and seniors, you did have options.
Describe as much as you can recall that first semester academically.
What were those classes like for a boy from Louisiana?
Well, the classes in the first year, I remember Tom Harrington taught chemistry.
Oh, describe him as a teacher.
He was a wonderful guy.
But he taught chemistry, and he also took people on tours to Europe every year.
And he was a very broad-gauge teacher.
guy and was very stimulating to the students, I'd say.
But he had large classes, but I later got to know Tom quite well.
Did he have a nickname?
Did the students give him a nickname?
I don't remember.
So many of them did have, but I don't remember Tom having any nickname.
He was from up here at McKinney originally.
Plano.
Plano, right.
Plano and McKinney, I knew that.
But then the other classes... Well, not English.
Do you remember a special?
Oh, yes, I do know English.
John Paul Abbott was the
I remember really stimulated me as far as English was concerned.
And he also was the tennis coach.
And I played tennis.
I was on the varsity in tennis and played several years.
Describe him as a teacher.
As a teacher, he was stimulating.
And as a matter of fact, when I was a sophomore,
They had the William Morris Sophomore Writing Contest.
And the prize was $25, which was a lot of money at that time.
And I won the thing.
I won the William Morris, but John Paul Abbott was helpful in my, because I went to him from time to time and got his advice on things.
And I wrote a, my paper was on Huey P. Long.
which was sort of an interesting character that I knew a lot about from Louisiana.
I knew a lot of the things that actually newspapers didn't, and I think that was one of the reasons I won it, because it was sort of a yellow journalism.
But in my early days at A&M,
I went out for fish basketball, and I made the team, and I later played varsity at A&M.
Describe going out for the fish.
What was freshman basketball like then?
A whole bunch of people.
A lot of people who, and the coach had to cut pretty good to weed the people out.
Who was the coach?
At that time, I think the freshman coach was Higginbottom, but the varsity coach was John Reed, and who is, if you have talked to anybody about John Reed, he's a
a classic among basketball coaches.
I remember he, at one time, we couldn't hit, people for some reason weren't hitting the basket.
And so at the halftime, he brought a step ladder out and had everybody climb up the step ladder and dunk the ball in to show that it really would go through.
And then another time, we had a guy on the team who was sort of a, he wasn't passing the ball to other guys.
So at the half, Coach Reed said,
He said, you know, I thought everybody knew everybody here.
He said, Mr. Carmichael, I want you to meet Mr. Hutto.
Mr. Hutto, I want you to meet so-and-so.
And he introduced everybody.
But that was his style.
Describe the basketball arena then.
Well, the basketball arena then, it would seat about 3,500 people, I guess.
It's now torn down where it was.
Everybody went to the games.
I mean, it wasn't like now where you got this beautiful arena and only about a third of it was filled up, but everybody went to the games.
For freshmen, who did y'all play?
Well, we played
We played high school teams and mostly high school teams.
I can't remember us playing any college teams.
Most parts of freshmen just played high school teams.
And didn't go on the road much?
No, not on the road.
In the varsity, of course you did, but the freshmen you didn't play.
Did you get any benefit?
You didn't get a basketball scholarship or anything that fresh in here?
No, no.
I sort of got this for you that you might be interested in.
Let's see if I can find it.
Let's see here.
About how many were on that freshman team?
On the freshman team, we had been about 12 or 15, something like that.
And how tall were the tall boys?
The tall boys were probably six feet at that time.
Here's something I'd cut out.
Fish cages defeat thrall-high tigers.
And it says, Creighton midget forward from Louisiana started the game off with a bang by scoring the first goal on a perfectly executed tip-off signal.
And then later on, in my junior year,
Of course, I cut this out.
It said, the A&M basketball team always turned out to be the dark horse of the season.

After dropping seven of the first eight games, the Aggie quartet beat the TCU Frogs in a thrilling game, upset the dope when they easily outclassed SMU by a large scoring margin, and then they almost took the Texas U Longhorns in one of the most thrilling finishes of the season.
Few will deny a minute more would have seen the Aggies take the lead.
Jack Creighton's last two shots of the game stand out as one of the highlights of the season.
And you had asked me how that happened.
I later on played with an Army team, and we played an exhibition game against the world champion Celtics, and I was the high point man of the team.
My goodness.
Thank you, thank you.
Oh, that's splendid.
For you as a freshman,
About when did basketball workouts start and during the season?
They started early.
The basketball season started, I'd say, in September and went through December, I'd say.
For you, in your outfit, did being on the basketball team get you any advantages?
Oh yeah, it sure did.
And then varsity, you ate at the training table during the season, and you got steaks and so forth.
You didn't as a fish.
As a fish, you had no special privileges, but you had a training table at Sabisa Hall where you got special food, steak from now on in, you know.
Let's go back to your fish year.
Describe...
Describe a typical day that first semester, a class day.
What time did you get up?
What did you do when?
Take me through a whole day of a typical fish day in the fall of 1930.
What would this be, 33?
Reveille, I think Reveille was at 6 o'clock, and a bugle of blue Reveille.
You farmed outside, marched to the mess hall, and had breakfast, marched back.
You cleaned up the room orderly floor.
I was the room orderly floor.

for Charlie Swanson, and I cleaned up his room, made his bed, and washed the mirror, and scrubbed out the toilet, and saw that his room could pass inspection if it needed to, and then had to do the same thing for my own room.
After that, while you went to class, I think class was, I don't know exactly what time classes started, but at 8.30 and 9 o'clock, and you usually had three classes in the morning.
Then you broke for lunch, and you came back and you marched to the mess hall again.
Came back to your outfit, marched to the mess hall.
And then after lunch, while you had usually lunch,
labs.
Classes are labs, but labs were all in the afternoon.
And the usually labs were two or three hours.
And then after labs,
or after the afternoon session why you had some some free time and then you again marched to the mess hall for supper and then fish had to be in the hold at 7 30.
I remember that so they I forget what the
bugle call was, but they sounded the bugle call at 730.
You had to be in your hole, and actually inspections were made by the senior officers to be sure you were in your hole.
And then I think TAPS was at 11 o'clock, I think.
But it lights out then.
It taps.
And it was a full day.
And you also had physical education as one of your obligations.
And if you were on a
